newsitem.title: UK: UK wants to improve public transport - Robin Cook.
newsitem.headline: UK wants to improve public transport - Robin Cook.

text.p: British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook said on Monday the new Labour government aimed to make public transport more attractive and a viable alternative to the private car.
But he stressed his remarks should not be taken as implying that taxes on motoring would be increased in the July 2 budget.

In a telephone interview with BBC radio, Cook said Prime Minister Tony Blair would outline Britain's goal of cutting carbon dioxide emissions by 20 percent by 2010 in a speech to a United Nations environmental conference in New York today.
This would include "a change in transport policy to make public transport more attractive, more reliable, more an alternative option to private car use, which has escalated under the Conservatives."
"It's not a question of stopping people using private cars, It's giving them the alternative of public transport which will also give them a higher quality of life," Cook added.
Asked if his remarks should be taken as a hint that higher taxes on motoring would be included in the budget, Cook said this would be an "over-interpretation."
"What happens in the budget is a matter for the chancellor and you would not expect me to anticipate that," he said.
